We're gonna do some maths in the news - I like 
to do math in the news, and a headline caught

my eye recently which I saw which said 'Science 
confirms: Politics wrecks your ability to do

maths' which I think is the best headline ever, 
a fantastic headline - whoever wrote that earned

their money that time. So what was this all about? 
This was a recent study that has discovered that

people's politics, people's preconceived beliefs, 
are actually affecting their judgment. And they

measured this by giving them a maths problem to 
try. So let's have a look at what they did. So this

study was done by Dan Cohen of Yale University 
and others and they took 1,111 people and they

measured how good they were at maths, and they 
measured their politics; are they sort of left-leaning

people or are they right leaning people? And the first 
thing they did is they gave a group of them a

neutral question. So the question they gave them 
was, they asked them about a skin cream. They said,

this is a skin cream that we're testing that will 
reduce your rash, and this is the data that we got.

They have people who did use the cream, and then 
there were some people who did not use the cream.

And there were people who- there are people who 
made the rash better and there are people for

which it made the rash worse. So does the cream 
make it better or worse? And this is these are

the values that they gave in the question: so 223 
people here, 75 people there, 107 and 21. So the

first question was, does it make the rash- does 
the cream make the rash better or worse? Have a

quick look at those numbers, you might want to 
have a quick go at that yourself. I might ask

Brady, I might just drag him in. Do you think 
this is just making the rash better or worse?

(Brady: The cream's not helping.)
- Yeah. So when you look at those numbers, your first instinct might be

to see, well, you've got more people there that the 
the cream- the cream actually helped. So you might

think, oh well the cream helps, there's twice 
as many people it helped. But if you look over

here, looking at the people that it made worse, 
you actually have three times as many making

it worse. So this isn't going to help you really, 
your first instinct might be wrong in that case,

you have to look at the percentages. So if you 
do look at the percentages - how many people did

it cure? 223 out of - and in how many people were 
tested - 298. And that's about 75%.
And if you look at the people who did not use the cream, 107 people were cured out of 128.
This is about 84%. So what you've got here is the people who did not use the cream are actually getting better than the people who did use the cream.
So the correct- the correct conclusion is, don't use the cream. Right so that's the neutral question. And just for fairness,
they actually did the same question with the same numbers but with the opposite conclusion.
And what he discovered is that people who were bad at maths didn't do very well, they didn't get the right conclusion.
About 40% of people got the right conclusion which was probably partly guesswork.
People who were good at maths though could do this extra step, work out the percentages, and they would come to the right conclusion.
So far more people who are good at maths get the right conclusion

(Does that mean I'm good at maths because I got it right?)
- Yes, yes. Now next they did is they gave you a 
controversial question - does gun control reduce

crime? This is a controversial topic in the U.S, 
does gun control reduce crime? So does banning

concealed handguns reduce crime? And all they 
did was the same question again with the same

numbers. If you do the same procedure again, you 
should come to the right conclusions. In this

case the conclusion would be, the ban is better. Here 
you go, the ban is actually decreasing crime.

But then they, again, for fairness they did the 
same question with the opposite conclusion. Now,

this is where the problems start. The people who 
were bad at maths were again, very similar to the

other question, not doing very well on it. 40% of 
them were getting it right, getting the right

conclusion, again it's because they didn't have 
the maths to do it. The people who are good at

maths were doing it well unless it went against 
their political leanings. So the people who are

sort of right leaning were actually doing 
worse on this question that said banning guns is

a good idea; and the people who were left leaning 
we're doing worse on the other question that says

banning guns is a good idea. And they were equally 
guilty of this, people who were going left and right

politically were equally guilty of this, and their 
score dropped dramatically, from something like

80% of them getting it right dropping way down to 
40% often getting- really big difference. It shows

that people's belief does affect their judgment. 
What they think might be happening is, if your

conclusion kind of reinforces your preconceived 
ideas then you stop looking further. So in this

example here, you can see the 223 is bigger 
than 107 and you go, oh that confirms what I

already thought and you stop looking further. If it 
doesn't confirm what you already thought you go, oh

I don't like this, I've got to do something- are 
you sure? I don't believe you and you dig deeper,

that means you do that extra step of looking at 
the probabilities, and then you do the maths. That

forces you to do the maths and come to- hopefully 
come to the right conclusions. This is an important

study for people who need to communicate science. 
So communicating science to the general public,

there are some people who don't understand science
or don't understand mathematics, but it's not just

that, that's not the only problem. There are people 
who do understand science perfectly well and who

still let their beliefs cloud their judgments. This 
was a study on the general public, I hope that

trained mathematicians and trained scientists 
know not to fall for something like this, they

would do that extra step. And even if they did so, 
we have this thing called peer review; our working

needs to be checked by other scientists and by 
the mathematical community, by the scientific

community, and there's nothing a scientist or a 
mathematician likes more than correcting someone

who is wrong. It's kind of like the Internet in 
that respect. But for the general public, this is an

important- this is an important thing to consider 
when we're trying to communicate our research.
